newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Jewish militants oppose new Jerusalem mosque.
newsitem.headline: Jewish militants oppose new Jerusalem mosque.

text.p: A Jewish ultranationalist group said on Thursday the opening of a new mosque beneath Islamic shrines Jerusalem's Old City would be an intolerable crime against Jews.

"Temple Mount Faithful will not tolerate this grave and enormous crime against the Jewish people and opens the struggle to cancel the crime," the group said in a statement, without disclosing any plan of action.

On Wednesday, Jerusalem police detained seven Jewish militants who tried to force their way onto the Temple Mount, known to Moslems as Haram al-Sharif, to protest against the planned opening of a mosque in Solomon's Stables.
The stables, where 12th century Crusaders kept their war horses, is a one-acre (half-hectare) pillar-lined chamber under part of Haram al-Sharif, Islam's third holiest shrine.
Islamic religious authorities, the Waqf, has been renovating the chamber to house a mosque.
"The work is almost complete and it will very soon be open for prayers," Shaykh Mohammad Hussein, director of al-Aqsa mosque, above the stables, told Reuters.
The site, not far from an Israeli-excavated archaeological tunnel where the opening of a new entrance last month sparked fierce clashes which killed 75 Arabs and Jews, is controversial.

Israeli security sources said Israel and Waqf officials reached a secret deal in 1995 under which Israel would permit Moslem use of the stables for prayer in exchange for Waqf acquiescence at the opening of the tunnel entrance.
Israel's Jerusalem municipality said the work on the new mosque was conducted without a permit and violated city building laws.
"The city in September issued an order to stop building," a city spokeswoman said.

The municipality has not enforced the order, apparently fearing violent Arab reaction. But the spokeswoman said the Temple Mount Faithful -- who want to replace Moslem shrines with a rebuilt Jewish Temple -- had petitioned Israel's Supreme Court to halt the Waqf construction.
"We are waiting for the court's response," she said.
The Temple Mount Faithful often try to enter the Mount to hold Jewish prayers to press their claim to the site but are blocked by Israeli police.
